remarks.para: URL mapping provides a means of mapping a 's to one or more URLs. Using such URLs allows you to refactor your application while keeping the URLs constant. Mapped URLs can also be designed to be shorter and more readable than a URL containing the fully qualified type name of a . They are therfor also referred to as "friendly URLs".
Use this class's property to read the configuration settings from your code.

In order to use URL mapping for the execution engine, you must enter the mapping in an XML file and specify the physical path of the file in the executionEngine element of the remotion.web configuration section.
See the for details on registering the remotion.web configuration section.
See the for details on the executionEngine element in the configuration section.

Should you choose to use an extension other than ashx for your mapped URLs, you must register the file extension with IIS. If you do not intend to use marker files, uncheck the "Verifiy that file exists" flag in the application extension configuration.
The extensions can be registered in the property pages of the web site (property page "Home Directory") or the virtual directory/application (property page "Virtual Directory"). The list of registered application extensions can be accessed via the "Configuration" button. Add a new mapping between the extension and the ASP.NET ISAPI dll (%SystemRoot%\Microsoft.net\Framework\v1.1.4322\aspnet_isapi.dll. You should enable at least the following verbs: GET, HEAD, POST, DEBUG. Uncheck the "Verifiy that file exists" option.
You also have to register the (or a derived version) in your application's configuration file. The following code snipped shows how to register the extension wxe for the standard .
<system.web> <httpHandlers> <add verb="*" path="*.wxe" type="Remotion.Web.ExecutionEngine.WxeHandler, Remotion.Web" /> </httpHandlers> </system.web>

Place a copy of the UrlMapping.xsd schema file into Visual Studio's xml schema directory (C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio .NET 2003\Common7\Packages\schemas\xml) to provide IntelliSense for the mapping file.

Class.example:
An example for specifying the urlMappingFile attribute with the executionEngine configuration section element.
<remotion.web xmlns="http://www.re-motion.org/web/configuration"> <!-- The configuration section entries. --> <executionEngine urlMappingFile="C:\ProjectDirectory\UrlMapping.xml" <!-- Other elements of the executionEngine section. --> /> <!-- Other configuration section entries. --> </remotion.web>

The following example shows an XML file that contains the following mappings:
A of MyNamespace.MyFirstFunction,MyAssembly mapped to the URLs ~/first.wxe and ~/primary.wxe. The first mapping also has an ID: First.
A second of MyNamespace.MySecondFunction,MyAssembly mapped to the URL ~/second.wxe. The second mapping also has an ID: Second.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <urlMapping xmlns="http://www.re-motion.org/Web/ExecutionEngine/UrlMapping/1.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.re-motion.org/Web/ExecutionEngine/UrlMapping/1.0 UrlMapping.xsd"> <add id="First" type="MyNamespace.MyFirstFunction,MyAssembly" resource="first.wxe"/> <add id="Second" type="MyNamespace.MySecondFunction,MyAssembly" resource="second.wxe"/> <add type="MyNamespace.MyFirstFunction,MyAssembly" resource="primary.wxe"/> </urlMapping>
